expose.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to show something that is usually covered or hidden
expose.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: He lifted his T-shirt to expose a jagged scar across his chest.
Potatoes turn green when exposed to light.
expose.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to put someone in a situation where they are not protected from something dangerous or unpleasant
expose.translation[0].definitions[1].not: expose yourself to ridicule/criticism etc (=say or do something that may make people laugh at you, criticize you etc)
expose.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: The report revealed that workers had been exposed to high levels of radiation.
expose.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to show the truth about someone or something, especially when it is bad
expose.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: The film exposes the utter horror of war.
The report exposes the weaknesses of modern medical practice.
The baron was exposed as a liar and a cheat.
expose.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to make it possible for someone to experience new ideas, ways of life etc
expose.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Some children are never exposed to classical music.
expose.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to allow light onto a piece of film in a camera in order to take a photograph
expose.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to show other people feelings that you usually hide, especially when this is not planned
expose.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: I’m afraid I might expose my real feelings for him.
expose.translation[1].definitions[0].def: a story in a newspaper or on television that shows the truth about something, especially something dishonest or shocking
expose.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: an exposé of corrupt practices by lawyers
expose.translation[2].definitions[0].def: a newspaper article or a television programme which tells people the truth for the first time about something bad, or someone who has done something illegal, dishonest, or wrong
expose.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: a sensational exposé of insider dealing and corruption in the City
expose.translation[3].definitions[0].def: to reveal the truth about someone or something that was hidden, especially when it involves something illegal, dishonest, or wrong
expose.translation[3].definitions[0].exa: He achieved political prominence by exposing high-level corruption.
expose.translation[3].definitions[1].def: to put goods in a place where people can see them or buy them
expose.translation[3].definitions[1].exa: The products do not have to be exposed at the supplier’s premises.
Instead of displaying so many high-definition TVs, they could expose the cheaper sets.
